Comments_List: The course is pretty nice. I learned a lot about convex optimization. Primal-dual methods, ADMM, gradient descent, and many more.
A taste of optimization skills.
This course helps me to develop theoretical foundation in some widely adopted algorithms, to review and learn diverse optimization tasks and methods in a systematic way.
a comprehensive knowledge in optimization
convex optimization
Solid Optimization math skills
I learned many different optimization techniques.
I developed insights into optimization theory and techniques, also both theoretical and computational skills in this field.

Concept of convex sets and functions. Gradient decent algorithm, Newton method, duality theory, convex optimization, interior point method. Mainly theoretical aspect of the algorithms (e.g., rigorous proof of performance scaling like # of iteration steps for given error threshold).

Challenging introduction to the field--but it gives both low and high level insights into why optimization and convexity matter. You also gain a lot of practical tricks for working with inequalities and matrices and taking more difficult derivatives. Motivates aspects of calculus and linear algebra very effectively.
Better ability to read optimization literature.
I learned classic and new techniques in optimization algorithms in this course.
Deeper understanding of optimization techniques.
I think the course is pretty well balanced and nothing should be changed.
Very helpful to know about and apply optimization techniques.

The lectures are very informative and the problem sets help a lot in consolidating our knowledge. Dr. Tatikonda and Xinyang are very accessible and give us useful advice and feedback. My only suggestion is that maybe we can also have some programming/numerical experiments in the homework to help us develop detailed understanding in some aspects that are important but easily omitted (like tuning parameters, etc)
a comprehensive knowledge in optimization
Teach a little fast.

The lectures were very good. I wish the notes for every lecture were available to the students so I could spend all my attention on the lecture rather than devoting attention to rapidly writing down what was on the chalkboard. Often, professor would ask if anyone had any questions and people seldom did. I believe that some students would have had questions and would have been able to ask them if they were more engaged in the verbal aspect of the lecture rather than note taking.
Weakness - too theoretical and professor provides little intuition. Many proofs are similar, and I'd like more of a theory intuition as opposed to jumping directly into the proofs.
The course is well organized and well instructed. It will be better if slides or ppt of class content is provided.
Only weakness was courses progressing veery fast. I had hard times following the content, often times the writings on the wall was being erased before I could write all of them.
Yes. I think every student in the stem should have some basic idea about convex optimization.
Yes.
Yes. This is possibly a theoretical-oriented course, but taught in a way that is easy to understand.
yes
yes
Yes, I would recommend this course. The concepts that were covered in this course are very important and I feel that many students would benefit from taking this course.
I would recommend because this course is highly insightful as well as useful.

If comfortable with basics of vector calculus, linear algebra and proof based math, and have clear motivation, I would highly recommend the course. It may be even better if there is an explicit optimization problem to solve for the final project before choosing the course.
It seems a requirement in today's world, but make sure you have the mathematical chops to keep up. I did not and struggled.
I would recommend this course to a student who needs to use optimization in his research or studies.
Definitely. I provides you to see alternative ways according to problem type.
